120139 120139 S0926-860X(25)00040-7 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120139 The Authors Fig. 1 Time online profile for Guerbet reaction using Ru PPhenbipy, homogeneous [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl catalyst and Ru/C heterogeneous catalyst. Conversion (solid lines) with Ru PPhenbipy (black line; solid square), [Ru(pcym)(dppm)Cl]Cl (orange line; open square) and Ru/C (Blue line; half open square). Associated Guerbet product selectivities to n-butanol (dotted lines). Reaction conditions: batch autoclave reactor, 150 °C, solventless reaction with 2.5 mol% NaOH. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Ru PPhenbipy catalyst batch recycle testing. Catalyst recovered by centrifugation and dried between re-use. Fresh ethanol used for each subsequent recycle run, aside from the “water removal” data in which water was removed and the original product mixture was returned to the reactor. Each reaction for 16 h, 150 °C, with 2.5 mol% NaOH. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) FT-IR spectra and (b) TGA profiles for fresh Ru PPhenbipy (black), Ru/PPhenbipy after 16 h postreaction (red) and after reaction with the addition of H2O (blue). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Solid-state (a) 13C NMR, (b) 1H NMR spectrum and (c) The structure for fresh (black) and used (red) Ru PPhenbipy catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Ruthenium K-edge XAFS of fresh and used Ru PPhenbipy catalysts. (a) Ruthenium K-edge XANES of Ru PPhenbipy samples and relevant standards. (b) The magnitude of the FT of Ru K-edge EXAFS for Ru PPhenbipy samples. Fresh Ru PPhenbipy (black); Used Ru PPhenbipy 2 h reaction (green); used Ru PPhenbipy 16 h reaction (red); used Ru PPhenbipy 16 h +water reaction (blue)Ru foil (purple dashed); RuO2.xH2O (blue dashed). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 High angle annular dark field (HAADF) STEM images of (a, b) fresh Ru PPhenbipy catalyst, (c,d) the catalyst after 2 hours of reaction (e, f) the catalyst after 16 hours of reaction respectively. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS analysis of the Ru 3dregion fresh and used Ru PPhenbipy catalysts. Fresh catalyst (a), 2 h used catalyst (b) and 16 h used catalyst (c). Experimental counts (grey), background (orange), fitting envelope (black) Ru (blue shaded), CC (green), C-C/C-H (red), C-O (light blue), OC-O (purple). Bioethanol upgrading to n-butanol is catalysed by homogeneous catalysts under mild solventless liquid phase conditions, at which heterogeneous catalysts have poor performance. Here a heterogeneous catalyst, initially comprised of a Ru(bipy) complex incorporated into a polyphenylene support, gave a catalytic performance (TON of 3565 Ru−1 and 82 % n-butanol selectivity) that exceeded contemporary homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Catalyst deactivation by water byproduct inhibition was improved by removal of water, via recharging the reactor with fresh ethanol, or by the co-addition of molecular sieve. The Ru polyphenylene catalyst showed greater stability in the presence of molecular sieve compared to the homogeneous catalyst, enabling high butanol yields. Characterisation showed a structural transformation of the single atom Ru(bipy) into 2.6 nm Ru(0) nanoparticles after 16 h reaction. While the Ru(0) had moderate recyclability (TON of 1000 Ru−1) the initial highly active species seen in the fresh catalyst are not stable. Graphical Abstract Key words Polymer catalysts Guerbet reaction Biofuels Bridging homogeneous/heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Due to their contribution to CO2 emissions and finite availability, non-renewable fossil fuels require urgent replacement [1,2]. Biofuels, produced from waste or surplus biomass, are regarded as a possible “drop-in” alternative for these fossil fuels. While not without controversy over resource competition with food crops, and the emergence of alternative green electrified transport options, biofuels do provide a rapid solution to improve the sustainability of modes of transportation that are not easily electrified. Bioethanol, easily produced from fermentation routes, is a well-established biofuel that is blended with gasoline [3,4]. However, challenges with corrosion, low energy density and its hygroscopic nature, limit the concentration of ethanol that can be added to fuel. Longer chain alcohols, such as n-butanol or iso-butanol, have comparable energy densities to gasoline, are non-corrosive and are also hydrophobic. These improved properties make butanol an advanced biofuel [5,6]. Acetone-butanol-ethanol (ABE) fermentation is a potentially green process for commercial butanol production. However, challenges with low yield and reaction efficiency are significant drawbacks [7,8]. Alternative, scalable chemical routes are therefore of great interest. The Guerbet reaction is the catalytic self-condensation of ethanol for long chain alcohol formation and represents an attractive route to produce n-butanol [9]. As shown in Scheme 1, the Guerbet reaction, utilises hydrogen borrowing from the initial alcohol via a metal catalysed rate limiting dehydrogenation reaction step [10–12]. Between these steps, aldol coupling is base mediated and produces water, known to deactivate many catalysts employed in the reaction. A lack of observed aldehyde intermediates is often attributed to dehydrogenation being rate limiting, although challenges in analytical detection, due to low boiling points and high reactivity, are a concern regarding proof of the mechanistic pathway and attaining reasonable carbon balances. Despite these concerns, the development of efficient hydrogen borrowing catalysts has been shown to be key to the technical development of this important reaction. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts are active for the ethanol to n-butanol transformation [11]. Wass et al. reported a Ru-bis(diphenylphosphino)methane homogeneous catalyst (1: Scheme 2), formed in-situ from [RuCl2(η6-p-cymene)]2, which achieved 20.4 % ethanol conversion and 90 % n-butanol selectivity with an alkoxide base at 150 °C (204 TON) [13]. However, the catalyst underwent deactivation and decomposed into Ru nanoparticles in the presence of water [5,13]. Milstein et al. [5] achieved high ethanol conversion and exceptional TON (48.1 %, 18209 TON) albeit with lower selectivity (79.4 %) using a Ru pincer complex (Scheme S1) at the same reaction temperature. In the same year, Tseng and co-workers achieved an ethanol conversion of over 50 % (78 % selectivity, 530 TON, 150 °C) using an air-stable amide-derived N,N,N-Ru(II) complex (Scheme S1) [14]. Recently, DiBenedetto and co-workers found that the Ru(II) bipyOH (6,6′-dihydroxybipy) homogeneous catalyst (Scheme S1) achieved 21 % n-butanol yield with 50 % n-butanol selectivity in an aqueous solution at a lower reaction temperature of 80 °C [15]. In summary, excellent activity and reasonable selectivity has been achieved using homogeneous catalysts at relatively low temperatures, yet limitations are often observed, including the need for high catalyst concentrations (0.02–1.5 mol%) and challenges in catalyst recovery and stability. Heterogeneous catalysts have also been developed for butanol production with reactions performed at higher temperatures in both the liquid and vapour-phase. Riittonen and co-workers found that Ru/Al2O3 can promote the ethanol to n-butanol transformation in the liquid phase (30 % selectivity, 2 % conversion) without the addition of base [16]. Poliakoff and co-workers found that Cu/CeO2 was active to ethanol transformation in a flow reactor with supercritical CO2 and ethanol , providing 47 % conversion and 31 % selectivity of n-butanol [17]. The use of solid basic catalysts, such as hydroxyapatite or spinel (MgAl2O4) catalysts have also been effective in promoting ethanol upgrading, but required temperature of ca. 500 °C [18]. To achieve the activity observed with homogeneous catalysts, better dispersed and highly active transition metals are required, in particular to promote the rate-limiting dehydrogenation reaction step. The concept of single atom catalysts to bridge homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis (recyclable; high selectivity and conversion) is an exciting and emerging research area that is applicable to the Guerbet reaction. Recently, Zhang et al. reported atomic Ru supported on a MgAl hydrotalcite, exhibiting 70 % n-butanol selectivity and 29.6 % ethanol conversion at 350 °C [19]. Guo et al. showed that high ethanol conversion can be achieved (65 % conversion at a selectivity of 50.2 %) using atomically dispersed Cu(I) also supported on a MgAl hydrotalcite support when high pressure (300 psi) was applied [20]. Yet, the concept can be developed beyond that of controlling the nuclearity of a reactive metal, by utilising surface organometallic chemistry [21]. In this case, a metal complex with a defined ligand environment interacts with the support via covalent or ionic bonds, with the support in effect being a macro-ligand. Recently an active (NNN) Ru pincer catalyst (Scheme S1) was modified to be anchored onto different Al2O3 supports and found to be active for ethanol upgrading, but not recyclable [22]. Goldberg and co-workers showed that molecular Ir pentamethycyclopentadienyl and Ru hexamethylbenzene complexes (Scheme S1) can be integrated into a poly(triazine)imide support and used as active catalysts for ethanol upgrading to butanol, unfortunately again with high catalyst concentration (1.5 mol%) and poor recyclability [23]. Recently, Wang et al [24,25] designed a Ru(III) polymer framework catalyst, PPhen-[bipy-RuIIICl4]H, in which Ru(III) was bound to the bipyridine within the polyphenylene backbone to create single atom [bipy-RuCl4]-. In this case the Ru metal centre is truly incorporated into the framework and represents a departure from studies in which a homogenous catalyst complex is grafted onto a framework. In this study, we explore how this PPhen-[bipy-RuIIICl4]H (referred herein as Ru PPhenbipy, 2: Scheme 2) catalyst can perform in the Guerbet reaction, under the mild reaction conditions utilised by homogeneous catalysts. Importantly, we directly compare this catalyst with contemporary homogeneous and heterogenous catalysts under the same reaction conditions. We focus on catalyst stability and how deactivation can be mitigated through water removal from the reaction. Furthermore, we investigate changes to the catalyst structure, via high resolution electron microscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy, to understand how the Ru local structure is influenced by reaction conditions and therby provide insight into possible deactivation mechanisms. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Ruthenium (III) chloride hydrate (RuCl3•xH2O, 99.9 %) was purchased from strem. 5,5′-Dibromo-2,2′-bipyridine was purchased from Apolloscientific. 1,4-benzenediboronic acid, 96 %, K2CO3 (≥99.0 %), methanol, ethanol and Na2EDTA·2 H2O were supplied by Fisher Scientific and used without purification. Dodecane was purchased from Merck. Ruthenium(III) nitrosyl nitrate solution (in dilute nitric acid, Ru(NO)(NO3)x(OH)y, x + y = 3, Ru 1.5 wt%), 1,2,4,5-tetrabromobenzene (97 %), 2,2′-Bipyridine, dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.8 %) and activated charcoal (DARCO®, 100 mesh particle size) were purchased from Merck Life Science UK Limited, and used without any purification. 2.2 Ru PPhenbipy catalyst synthesis The synthesis method for polyphenylene framework with bipyridine sites (PPhenbipy) has been adapted from Wang et al [24]. Specifically,1,2,4,5-tetrabromobenzene (1.316 g, 3.340 mmol), 5,5′-dibromo-2,2′-bipyridine (0.342 g, 1.09 mmol), 1,4-benzenediboronic acid (1.290 g, 7.780 mmol), K2CO3 (2 M aqueous solution, 15 mL) and Pd(PPh3)4 (0.30 g, 0.26 mmol) were placed into a 250 mL Schlenk flask with degassed DMF (120 mL) under N2. Three freeze-pump-thaw cycles were then used to fully remove O2. The mixture was refluxed under Ar at 150 °C for 20 h and a dark green precipitate was formed. K2CO3 and DMF were then extracted using 600 mL H2O for 30 min. The solid was filtered and washed with H2O and MeOH. The dark green product (1.703 g) was added to a 200 mL solution mixture (30 % H2O2, 37 % HCl, H2O and EtOH with ratio of 1:5:5:10 in volume) at room temperature, before being heated to 60 °C for 4 h. The resultant light-yellow solid was filtered and washed with H2O and MeOH. The product was vacuum dried at 60 °C. To remove residual Pd, the solid (1.141 g) was washed in a 228 mL solution mixture (32 % NH4OH, H2O and EtOH with ratio of 1:15:30 in volume) with 11.41 g Na2EDTA·2 H2O. for 24 h at 70 °C. The final yellow solid was filtered, washed with H2O and MeOH and vacuum dried at 60 °C. Ru loading was performed as follows; PPhen-bipy and RuCl3·3 H2O (the mass ratio between these two reagents is 1 g to 150 mg) were added to a solution of 10 % HCl and EtOH (50 mL). After stirring at 70 °C for 5 h, the reddish-brown precipitate was filtered, washed and dried as above. 2.3 Homogeneous catalyst preparation [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl was synthesised by using the procedure described by Wass et al [13], in which the compound was synthesised in-situ in a batch reactor under catalytic conditions (vide infra). [Ru(bipy)Cl4]- (3: Scheme 2) was produced using the method reported by Krause et al [26]. RuCl3·3 H2O (1000 mg, 4.82 mmol) and 2,2′-bipyridine (220.0 mg, 1.41 mmol) were added into 5 N HCl. The mixture was stirred under ambient conditions for 30 mins and left to stand for 3 weeks. The black powder was collected and washed with water and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum (yield: 1.40 g, 92 %). 2.4 Ru/C catalyst synthesis The 4 wt% Ru/C (4 g) was prepared used a wet impregnation method [27]. Ruthenium(III) chloride (0.33 g, 1.59 mmol) and 17 mL deionised water were added in to a 50 mL round bottom flask at 60 °C. The activated charcoal (3.84 g) support was added slowly over a period of 15 min with constant stirring. The temperature was then changed to 90 °C for 16 h to evaporate the solvent. The catalyst was reduced under 5 % H2/Ar (450 °C, 4 h, 20 mL/min) for removing the chloride from the material. 2.5 Catalytic reaction testing The catalytic reactions were carried out in a batch configuration using a 100 mL Parr stainless steel autoclave with aluminium heating block and magnetic stirring. PPhen-[bipy-RuIIICl4]H (100 mg, 0.006 mol% Ru), NaOH (2.5 mol%) and ethanol 100% (40 mL, 685 mmol) were added into the vessel and heated to 150 °C for 2–48 h. After reaction, the autoclave was cooled to approx. 40 °C and then put in the ice bath for further cooling. The post reaction solution was analysed by GC-FID using a HP 6890 with a Carbowax column (methanol as solvent and n-dodecane as internal standard). Method: starting oven temp 60 °C, hold for 2 min, heating to 180 °C at 20 °C min−1, hold at 180 °C for 4 min, finally heating to 230 °C at 20 °C min−1, hold at 230 °C for 2 min. Permanent gases of H2, CO and CH4 were analysed by GC-TCD using a Agilent 8860 with a ShinCarbon column. The catalytic reactions for homogeneous catalyst were carried out following the procedure of Wass and co-workers. RuCl2[(η6-p-cymene)]2 was added to the reaction (comparable moles of Ru to heterogenous reactions stated above) with an equivalent of dppm. The active catalyst formed in-situ within the reaction. Calculations were carried out as follows: % Conversion = [ P n ] [ R i ] × 100 % % Selectivity = P ∑ [ P n ] × 100 % % Carbon Selectivity = ( molsP × C n ) ∑ ( P n × C n ) × 100 % Turnover number ( TON ) = mol P n mol Ru Turnover frequecy ( TOF ) = mol P n at 2 h reaction time mol Ru . ( 2 h ) where Ri denotes the initial reactant, Pn denotes liquid phase Guerbet products formed during the catalysis (n-butanol, n-hexanol, 2-ethyl butanol and 2-ethyl hexanol) and where relevant gas phase products, P denotes the specific product using for calculation, Cn carbon number of product. Solid phase sodium acetate by product, identified by solid state NMR, could not be quantified despite attempts by TGA due to the concentration of this product relative to the heterogeneous catalyst also present. 2.6 Catalyst characterisation Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of solid samples were recorded using a Bruker D8 Discover diffractometer using monochromated Co Kα1 radiation (Kα1 = 1.789 Å) at 35 kV and 40 mA over the 2 theta range 25–80 using a 0.03 two theta step over a period of 59 mins using a Vantec detector. Wavelength-Dispersive X-ray Fluorescence (WD-XRF) spectroscopy was conducted using a Rigaku Primus IV system, equipped with a 4 kW Rh tube. The calculated area densities of the samples were also used to apply a weight thickness correction to the measured intensities. The carbon (C), hydrogen (H) and nitrogen (N) content of the catalysts were measured by Exeter CE-440 Carbon Hydrogen Nitrogen (CHN) analyser. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using 5 mg of sample in an aluminium crucible. Samples were heated to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of air (70 mL/min). A smoothing function was used to remove vibrational noise from the profiles. STEM samples were prepared by dispersing samples in ethanol as a solvent. Data for the fresh sample and 16-h sample were collected using an aberration-corrected JEOL ARM-200F system at 80 kV, whereas the 2-h sample data were acquired with the aberration-corrected JEOL GrandARM system operating at 300 kV. Ru K edge XAS studies were performed at B18 at Diamond Light Source, Didcot, U.K. Measurements were performed using the QEXAFS setup with a fast-scanning Si (311) double crystal monochromator. On average, three scans of each sample were acquired and merged to improve signal-to-noise. All samples were run in transmission in self-supported pellets. XAS data processing was performed using IFEFFIT with the Demeter package (Athena and Artemis). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected on the Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer at the Photoemission RTP, University of Warwick. Samples were attached to electrically conductive carbon tape and electrically isolated. Measurements were conducted using a monochromated Al Kα x-ray source (hν = 1486.7 eV) at a take-off angle of 90°. The work function and binding energy scale of the spectrometer were calibrated using the Fermi edge and 3d5/2 peak recorded from a polycrystalline Ag sample. Samples were charge neutralised throughout the experiment and this necessitated recalibration of the binding energy scale. To achieve this, the C-C/C-H component of the C 1 s spectrum was referenced to 285.0 eV. The data were analysed in the CasaXPS package using Shirley backgrounds and mixed Gaussian-Lorentzian (Voigt) line shapes. Solid state NMR measurements were recorded on a JEOL ECZ-500 500 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a broadband 3.2 mm MAS solid state probe. Samples were packed into a 3.2 mm zirconia rotor with spacer, Vespel end caps, and spun at 15 KHz. The 90° pulse widths were measured for 1H (3.2 us) and 13C (3.1 us), and these values used for direct polarization (MAS) and cross polarisation (CP-MAS) experiments. 1H MAS experiments were obtained using 8 scans, 1024 data points giving an 8.2 ms acquisition time, a recycle delay of 2 s, and an x-offset of 0 ppm with a sweep of 200 ppm. 13C CP-MAS experiments were obtained with a cross polarisation mixing time of 1.2 ms with ramped gradient, 256 scans, 2048 data points giving an acquisition time of 32 ms, a recycle delay of 10 s, and an x-offset of 100 ppm with a sweep of 300 ppm. Decoupling was carried out during acquisition using TPPM (Two Pulse Phase Modulation decoupling) noise at 15.2 dB. N2 absorption experiments were performed with a Micromeritics GeminiVII at 77 K. The surface area was calculated with BET method. Before each measurement, the sample was degassed in vacuum at 150 °C overnight. CO chemisorption experiments were conducted using an Altamira AMI-300Lite. Ca. 100 mg catalyst was loaded in U tube between quartz wool. The sample was reduced under pure H2 (30 cc in flow) at 150 °C (30 min, ramp rate: 10 °C /min), followed by He treatment at 150 °C (30 min, 30 cc in flow). CO titration was performed at 100 °C with 10 % CO/He by pulsing through a 574 μL sample loop. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) data were collected at Bruker Vertex 80, Harrick (praying Mabtis™) ZnSe cell window. Before measurement, sample was calcined at 150 °C, 10 °C/min with pure H2 (30 mL/min, 150 °C, 5 min). The IR background was collected after cooling the sample to 25 °C with Ar flow (30 mL/min). CO titration was performed at room temperature. Spectrum range was set from 4000 cm−1 to 650 cm−1; taking 30 spectra with 30 s for each spectrum. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst testing The Ru PPhenbipy catalyst was successfully synthesised, with a 4 wt% loading of mononuclear Ru species, as proven by relevant characterisation techniques (vide infra catalyst characterisation Section 3.2). We employed this catalyst in the Guerbet reaction under mild conditions (1 bar Ar, 150 °C, ethanol as reagent) in a batch reactor, equivalent to those used for the well-established homogeneous ([Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl) catalyst [13]. NaOH was utilised as the base to promote aldol-coupling at concentrations previously reported. Given that dehydrogenation is considered the rate limiting step of the reaction, the influence of base concentration was not significantly explored in this study [12]. The catalytic performance of Ru PPhenbipy, ([Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl) and a supported Ru/C heterogeneous catalyst is shown in Table 1, with time online analysis being reported in Fig. 1. To ensure that the choice of base didn’t have a significant impact we compared the performance of Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl in 2.5 %mol% NaOH and NaOEt and found no notable difference in performance (Table S1). The Ru PPhenbipy catalyst resulted in 25.9 % ethanol conversion with 81.9 % n-butanol selectivity to Guerbet products over 16 h reaction time (Table 1), after which time no further conversion was observed. A TOF (based on total metal content) at 2 h was 970 h−1, while the final TON of the catalyst was 3565 Ru−1 (determined at16h reaction time, due to no further conversion at longer times). In addition to n-butanol, the remaining Guerbet products comprised of longer chain alcohols (n-hexanol, 2-ethylhexanol, and 2-ethyl butanol) (Table S1). No aldehyde intermediates or ester byproducts products were observed, in part due to the volatility and high reactivity of these species. Gas phase hydrogen, carbon monoxide and methane were also formed (mmol in Figure S1 and selectivity in Table 1), due to ethanol decomposition [16], with a carbon selectivity to gas products of 1.5 %. A PPhenbipy catalyst without Ru inclusion was found to result in 2 % ethanol conversion over 2 h, presumably due to residual Pd impurities found within the catalyst from its synthesis (vide infra catalyst characterisation section). By comparison, the in situ homogeneous ([Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl) catalyst previously reported by Wass and co-workers [13], resulted in an ethanol conversion of 6.3 % and a n-butanol selectivity of 89.8 % at 16 h. As observed with Ru PPhenbipy, the activity of the homogenous catalyst plateaued by 16 h. The lower ethanol conversion observed in this study, compared to that reported previously at comparable 16 h reaction time [13] (6.6 vs 20.4 %), is attributable to the reduced catalyst concentrations used in the present study (0.006 vs 0.1 mol%). Notably, the TON for [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl, which accounts for Ru concentration, was higher in the present study at 1073 Ru−1 vs 204 Ru−1 reported by Wass. [13] Such variance in catalytic activity with concentration highlights the importance of comparing different catalysts under identical conditions, as is the case within this study. As a further point of comparison, the catalytic performance of the homogeneous analogue of PPhen-[bipy-RuIIICl4] was found to be equivalent to [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]. The observed TOF of the heterogeneous Ru PPhenbipy (970 h−1) was notably higher than those seen for the homogeneous catalyst at 255 h−1. As seen from the time online profiles both catalysts deactivated over 16 h, although reactions performed with Ru PPhenbipy reached notably higher ethanol conversion in this time resulting in an appreciably greater TON. Interestingly, gas phase products from [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl] reactions were present in similar concentrations to Ru PPhenbipy, but given the lower ethanol conversion, gas carbon selectivity was notably higher than with the single site catalyst at 7.2 %. Therefore, while not eliminated by using Ru PPhenbipy, the undesired ethanol decomposition side reaction was suppressed relative to the well-established homogeneous catalyst. Finally, the catalytic performance of Ru PPhenbipy was considered in the context of a conventionally prepared 4 wt% Ru nanoparticles supported on carbon (Ru/C). The fresh catalyst is formed of 9 nm Ru supported on carbon (determined by XRD; Figure S2). Surface oxide or smaller non-detectable species reduced to Ru(0) under reaction conditions according to TPR analysis (Figure S3). Therefore, the catalyst represents an archetypal Ru(0) catalyst used in alcohol hydrogenation reactions and a good representative for catalytic activity of metallic ruthenium nanoparticles [28]. The Ru/C catalyst gave only 2.2 % ethanol conversion over 16 h (TON 375 Ru−1) with a 92 % selectivity to n-butanol. The low selectivity to n-butanol at short reaction times being accounted for by the very low ethanol conversion observed. In contrast to previously discussed catalysts, a further modest increase in conversion was seen between 16 and 48 h reaction time to give a final TON of 760 Ru−1 and 4.6 % ethanol conversion. The initial TOF of Ru/C, calculated from total Ru, was determined to be 50 h−1. However, considering that Ru dispersion in nanoparticle catalysts will clearly be < 100 %, the intrinsic activity of Ru/C was calculated using surface Ru sites (6.3 % dispersion as determined by CO chemisorption; vide infra catalyst characterisation) to give a TOF of 762 h−1. This value remains lower than the minimum possible Ru surface normalised TOF of 970 h−1 (assuming single atom-100 % dispersion) for Ru PPhenbipy, although now within the same order of magnitude. It is however notably greater than that calculated for [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl], although great care should be taken in overinterpreting this comparison between a discrete Ru(II) complex and an extended Ru(0) surface. Further, these values presume no Ru agglomeration within Ru PPhenbipy or [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl] during the reaction, which if present would notably increase their respective Ru dispersion normalised activity. Changes in catalyst structure were explored through a combination of catalyst reuse testing and post reaction characterisation as discussed below. 3.2 Catalyst reuse and water inhibition As seen from time online studies both the homogenous and Ru PPhenbipy undergo apparent deactivation. Whist detailed time online studies are not often reported in the literature for homogenous and other molecular supported catalysts, poor catalyst recyclability and deactivation has been noted [13,29]. In the case of homogeneous catalysts, deactivation has been attributed to water inhibition as a consequence of its production during aldol condensation and catalyst restructuring through reduction and the formation of metal precipitates. These deactivation mechanisms have therefore been explored with the Ru PPhenbipy catalyst and mitigation strategies developed. The recyclability of Ru PPhenbipy was tested ( Fig. 2) through 4 repeated 16 h reactions. Activity was observed on catalyst reuse, although ethanol conversion was found to have decreased compared to the initial first reaction (6.1 % vs 25.9 %). The cause of this decrease was attributable to catalyst restructuring, discussed in detail in the catalyst characterisation section. While most of the original activity of the catalyst was lost during the initial reaction, some catalytic performance was recoverable on using fresh reactant. Interestingly, similar ethanol conversions and selectivity were observed with a further two repeat reaction cycles, showing consistent TON of ca. 1000 Ru−1. Given that complete deactivation was seen during time online (Fig. 1) the relatively consistent 6 % conversion seen when the catalyst is recharged with fresh reactant suggests that water generated during the reaction directly inhibited reactivity. To further confirm this, the catalyst was recovered after an initial 16 h reaction and the water removed from the post reaction solution. On reintroduction of the catalyst to the dry solution a further 5.5 % increase in ethanol conversion was observed, giving a total conversion of 31.4 % over 32 h reaction time. The modest decrease in activity seen on catalyst recycling using this alternative method (i.e. water removal but otherwise retention of the same product mixture) was attributed to a modest loss of base and reduced ethanol concentration due to the presence of products. The direct effect of water on the Ru PPhenbipy activity was shown by spiking an initial reaction with 30 vol% water. A sharp decrease in ethanol conversion to 5.5 % over 16 h was observed (Table 1), which represents a 79 % decrease compared to a reaction without water spiking. The [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl] homogeneous catalyst also showed low water tolerance with a 88.4 % reduction in conversion, from 6.3 % to 0.73 % when adding water (Table 1), which had previously observed and was attributed to the promotion of Tishchenko and Cannizzaro side reactions [30]. Notably, the absolute conversion level observed with Ru PPhenbipy showed that the catalyst was able to function in the presence of water, unlike the almost absence of conversion seen with the homogeneous catalyst. A strategy employed previously by Wass [30] and Jones [31] to mitigate the detrimental impact of the water co-product was to sequester it in situ by introducing 3 Å molecular sieve to the reaction mixture. Wass observed relatively stable catalytic activity, with a modest 16 % decrease in ethanol conversion but reduced side product formation [30]. In repeating these findings an interesting interaction between the homogenous [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl]Cl catalyst and the zeolite was observed; highlighting the limited potential of this mitigation strategy with homogeneous catalysts. Reactions within this study were performed with a significantly lower catalyst concentration than reported by Wass and co-workers. Consequently, two different 3 Å molecular sieve concentrations required exploring to make a complete comparison. Firstly (Table 1), a comparable concentration of zeolite in ethanol to Wass was investigated (0.18 g mL−1). Unexpectedly, a reduction in ethanol conversion was observed of 4.5 % vs the original 6.6 % after 16 h, representing a 32 % decrease. Under these conditions it appears that molecular sieve causes catalyst deactivation. Yet, given the lower Ru concentration, the zeolite to Ru catalyst ratio differed vastly between that reported by Wass and the present work (17 g molRu −1 vs 175 g molRu −1 respectively). In the second reaction (Table 1) a comparable zeolite/Ru ratio (17 g molRu −1) was used, resulting in a minimal decrease in conversion (6.2 % vs 6.6 % at 16 h) and a modest increase in butanol selectivity, strongly supporting Wass’s previous findings. Therefore, while water removal using molecular sieve inhibits undesired side reactions, it also deactivates the [Ru(p-cym)(dppm)Cl] catalyst itself. The extent of this deactivation being dependent on the relative concentration of molecular sieve, with low concentrations limiting deactivation. Unfortunately, this limits the effectiveness of this strategy to low conversion levels as the water capacity of molecular sieve will be limited. The cause of deactivation was speculated to be due to undesired adsorption and reaction of the homogeneous complex and zeolite. Given that this interaction would be eliminated by using Ru species supported on a separate solid phase (i.e. a heterogeneous catalyst), the influence of 3 Å molecular sieve on Ru PPhenbipy was explored at the higher zeolite loading of 0.18 g mL−1 and 175 g molRu −1. Under these conditions the catalytic activity of Ru PPhenbipy over the 16 h reaction notably improved, with conversion increasing to 40.7 % (TON; 5007 Ru−1) from the original 25.9 % (TON; 3565 Ru−1) observed without the molecular sieve; this shows that removing generated water facilitates n-butanol production above that seen without the molecular sieve. The observed selectivity to n-butanol for the highly active Ru PPhenbipy- molecular sieve combination was 84.7 %, slightly greater than the 81.9 % without. By contrast, equivalently high loadings of molecular sieve deactivated the homogeneous catalyst, preventing significant improvement in n-butanol yield butanol above those seen without the molecular sieve. These findings provide an exciting proof of concept for enhancing Guerbet alcohol yields by eliminating undesired catalyst- molecular sieve interactions through using a highly active heterogeneous catalyst and molecular sieves. Despite this exciting finding the active site within Ru PPhenbipy undergoes restructuring and deactivation, as shown in the reuse testing in Fig. 2. Therefore, thorough characterisation of the initial catalyst and after reaction is required to understand and improve the activity and stability of this catalyst. 3.3 Catalyst characterisation 3.3.1 Analysis of polymer framework and adsorbed species Fresh Ru PPhenbipy was found to be amorphous with no observable reflections in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern (Figure S4), as observed previously by Wang and co-workers [32]. The lack of long range order was retained in all the used catalysts, showing no crystallisation of the framework, or agglomeration of Ru species into large crystallites during reaction. Bands within the FT-IR ( Fig. 3a) of fresh Ru PPhenbipy were assigned to the PPhenbipy framework (table S2) and in combination with a decomposition temperature of 393 °C in air, determined by TGA (Fig. 3b), confirmed that an analogous polyphenylene framework to that targeted had been synthesised [24]. After the 16 h reaction, the used Ru PPhenbipy retained the IR bands associated with the framework, but with additional bands at 2922, and 2850 cm−1 associated with aliphatic C-H stretching modes attributed to entrapped alcohol (ethanol/butanol) and possible acetate products. TGA analysis supports this assessment with mass loss events at 110 and 219 °C prior to framework decomposition, accounting for 26.3 % of the samples mass, both of which are attributed to entrapped alcohol. Water adsorption can be discounted as contact angle experiments (150° contact angle) showed that the polymer support was highly hydrophobic (Figure S5). Consequently, the higher ethanol conversions seen with Ru PPhenbipy can be partially explained by the ability of the PPhenbipy backbone to repel water during reaction. Simple adsorption tests under reaction temperatures and pressures (but with an absence of base to prevent activity) revealed that butanol and not ethanol absorbed into the polymer structure (TGA analysis shown in Figure S6). Interestingly, this shows that the ethanol reactant is only accessible to the external sites of the polymer. In addition to the low temperature mass losses, it was noted that the used polymer decomposition temperature reduced from 393 to 361 °C indicating subtle structural changes to the polymer after reaction. FT-IR analysis of the catalysts used in a reaction spiked with water showed no new bands, indicating it does not significantly alter the PPhenbipy structure or prevent n-butanol adsorption. However, TGA analysis showed a notably lower n-butanol loading, relative to the post 16 h reaction, and a polymer decomposition temperature between the fresh and 16 h reaction samples. Given that water addition significantly supressed butanol yield, the reduced butanol adsorption was not unexpected. 13C and 1H solid state NMR of fresh and used Ru PPhenbipy ( Fig. 4) was employed to further understand the polymer structure and changes during reaction. Two 13C signals at 139.2 and 128.2 ppm, associated with the expected sp2 carbon environments in the polyphenylene framework, were observed in the fresh material. In addition, 1H signals at 6.64 ppm and 2.71 ppm, correspond to the two expected environments within polyphenylene and bipy moieties of the framework. These findings support IR and thermal analysis that the intended PPhenbipy framework was synthesised. Post reaction 13C solid state NMR showed carbon environments associated with original polyphenylene framework, in addition to signals at 181.4 and 22.2 ppm associated with acetate (CH3COO-). Further evidence for these products was observed by the presence of a sharp signal at 1.3 ppm in the 1H solid state NMR of the used catalyst attributed to acetate. Acetate formation was further proven by 13C-1H correlations observed in the two-dimensional (2D) HETCOR spectrum (Figure S7). The presence of acetate is evidence of undesired Tishchenko and Cannizzaro reactions [30], previously observed in homogeneous catalysed reactions, also occurring with Ru PPhenbipy. Given no clear mass loss associated with sodium acetate was observed in TGA analysis it was concluded that this acetate product was present in relatively small concentartions. No evidence of alcohols was directly seen, which was attributed to the ill-defined environment of the entrapped species within the framework. However, a clear shift of the 1H signal associated with the polyphenylene framework from 2.71 ppm to 4.07 ppm implied that a possible OH species within the framework altered the protons local electronic environment [33]. 3.3.2 Elemental composition of fresh and used catalysts The elemental concentration of the fresh and used samples are shown in Table 2. The Ru concentration of the fresh Ru PPhenbipy of 4.0(2) wt% was slightly lower than the 5.8 wt% reported previously [24], but sufficient to perform the required catalytic reactions. Residual Pd was also observed within the sample from the Pd(0) Suzuki coupling catalyst used in polymer synthesis. Notable Cl content is present within the catalyst, from both polymer synthesis and as the associated ligand for the Ru(III) centre in the catalyst. After reaction the Ru concentration appears to have fallen, although this is not associated with leaching into reaction solution but from the mass gain of alcohol adsorption, as seen from the slight increase in C and H concentrations. Confirmation of a lack of Ru leaching was demonstrated by the absence of Ru within the effluent solution after 16 h reaction as determined by MP-AES (Table S3). Another notable change in elemental composition after reaction was the loss of Cl, which exceeds that associated with mass gain, and is attributable to leaching of chloride from the polymer and potentially a change in the ligand environment around the Ru centre. 3.3.3 Analysis of Ru active sites by XAFS and STEM Direct analysis of Ru local structure and its evolution during reaction was followed by Ru-K edge XAFS ( Fig. 5, S6&7 and Table 3). The EXAFS of the fresh catalyst fits the octahedral coordination environment of single atom Ru-bipy; with a Ru-N coordination number (CN) of 2, as expected for bidentate bipy binding, and a Ru-Cl of 4. The XANES of the fresh sample matched well with that previously reported by Wang and co-workers with an E0 of 22124 eV [24]. Analysis of the used catalysts show that the local environment of Ru dramatically changed after just 2 h reaction. Compared to the original fresh material, the XANES of the 2 h sample contains a notable pre-edge feature, clear splitting of the white line and a E(0) shift to 22127 eV (2 eV shift). This shift is less than that seen for Ru(IV)O2 formation, with an edge position of 22130 eV, showing that the bulk of the sample had not oxidised, and the presence of the pre-edge feature suggests a partial contribution of Ru(0). EXAFS analysis showed a complete loss of the Ru-Cl path, the presence of a Ru-O and an additional Ru-Ru path after the 2 h reaction. Fitting of the Ru-Ru path provides a distance closely associated with that of hcp Ru metal at 2.70 Å (ref: 40354 ICSD) and notably shorter than the 3.12 Å and 3.56 Å paths seen for bulk RuO2 (ref: 51159 ICSD). The Ru-Ru CN values observed are considerably below that of 12 seen in bulk Ru(0) and imply the presence of sub-nanometer clusters. While the presence of Ru-O scattering path indicates a passivating oxidic layer, it is anticipated that this would not be present under the reducing conditions of the Guerbet reaction, and is an artefact associated from sample handling in ambient conditions. Comparable paths, CNs and distances were observed by Wang and co-workers when they employed a pre-reduced Ru/PPhen catalyst in hydroxymethylfurfural hydrogenolysis [25]. At longer reaction times (8–48 h) all XANES and EXAFS spectra were equivalent to each other, but with subtle differences relative to the 2 h used catalyst (data for 8, 48 h and 4 ×16 h used catalysts are shown in Figures S8). Specifically, an increase in the Ru-Ru CN to 3.2(8) was observed after 16 h, which can be seen in the increased intensity of associated signal in the FT data. In addition, the pre-edge feature in the XANES associated with Ru(0) had marginally increased in intensity. After 4 × 16 h reaction cycles the CN for Ru(0) increased to 5(2). These changes are attributable to a further increase in Ru(0) particles size, although with CN values still well below that of bulk Ru(0). The spiking of the reaction with water resulted in no notable difference in the catalysts EXAFS, with a Ru-Ru coordination within error of the 16 h used catalyst. It can therefore be inferred that water did not directly influence catalyst structure but acts as a reversable catalytic inhibitor, as discussed above. Further evidence of this was seen in the post rection analysis of the catalyst with molecular sieve (Figure S8e), which showed an equivalent level of reduction and Ru(0) formation as the 16 post reaction sample. We further studied the Ru PPhenbipy catalysts before and after the reaction via high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) Z-contrast imaging using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). As shown in Fig. 6(a,b) the fresh catalyst mainly contains atomically dispersed Ru species, in agreement with XAFS analysis. In sharp contrast to the fresh sample, a significant amount of Ru-containing nanoparticles was found in the used catalysts (Fig. 6c, e) corroborating the changes seen by EXAFS. However, unlike EXAFS which is an averaging technique, some atomically dispersed species were still found to exist in the used samples by STEM (Fig. 6d, f). From these STEM images, particle agglomeration was seen between the catalyst used for 2 and 16 h from 1.6 ± 0.4–2.6 ± 0.9 nm, which indicated the aggregation of Ru particles with increased catalysis time (Figure S9). Care should be taken in the overinterpretation of the reported particle size distribution, due to the statistical challenge in accurately counting single atomic species through to relatively large nanoparticles [34]. However, it is clear that the size distribution broadened with reaction time. XPS spectra, shown in Fig. 7 (Ru 3d and C1s regions), Fig. 8 (Ru 3p3/2 and Cl2p regions) and in Table 4, also provides information on catalyst structure and evolution. Ru XPS spectra of fresh Ru PPhenbipy has a binding energy of Ru 3p 3/2 at 462.8 eV and Ru 3d 5/2 at 281.3 eV indicative of an oxidised Ru environment, relative to Ru(0) with binding energies of 461.7 eV and 279.8 eV for Ru 3p 3/2 and Ru 3d 5/2 respectively [35]. We note that the Ru 3d 5/2 and Ru 3p 3/2 binding energies were subtly different to all standards reported by Morgan [35], supporting the unique Ru environment determined by EXAFS. After reaction, the observed binding energies shift to lower energies of 280.9 eV and 462.3 eV (Ru 3p 3/2 and Ru 3d 5/2 respectively), confirming a partial reduction of Ru under the reaction conditions. The lack of complete reduction being evidence for the passivating oxide layer observed from EXAFS analysis. Further, it suggests that more reduced Ru(0) may be within the internal pore network of the polymer and inaccessible to XPS analysis. Of note, catalysts tested with spiked water showed an additional Ru feature associated with Ru-OH, indicating interaction with water and the Ru active site. The Cl 2p spectra for fresh and used PPhenbipy are shown in Fig. 8b. Binding energies at 197.8 eV (Cl 2p 3/2) and 199.4 (Cl 2p 1/2) are assigned to Ru-Cl in fresh Ru PPhenbipy. The spin-orbit splitting of features at 201.0 eV (Cl 2p3/2) and 202.62 eV (Cl 2p1/2) are best ascribed to C-Cl, which are probably due to the surface reaction the polymer with Cl- anions [36]. Notably all peaks below 200 eV are lost after 2 h reaction, confirming the loss of the Ru-Cl bonds associated with the fresh single atom species also noted by XRF and EXAFS analysis (Table 2 and Fig. 6). 3.3.4 Total and Ru specific surface area As discussed in Section 3.1.1, the dispersion of Ru within reference heterogeneous Ru/C was determined by CO chemisorption with a dispersion of 6.3 %. Given the observed reduction of [bipy-RuIIICl4] centres in Ru PPhenbiby after the Guerbet reaction (seen by XPS, XAFS and STEM) dispersion of this catalyst after different treatments was explored. Firstly, it is worthy of note that an N2 isotherm of the Ru PPhenbiby material showed that the material contained almost no microporosity with a type II isotherm being observed ( Fig. 9a). The surface area of the material was 15 m2g−1 in line with non-crosslinking PPhen frameworks produced within the literature and is not particularly gas permeable [33]. Given that neither component of the solvent used in Ru addition to PPhenbiby (ethanol and water) was absorbed into the polymer matrix, it is likely that all Ru was deposited on this relatively low surface area support. It is therefore noteworthy that a 4 wt% Ru loading could be atomically distributed at such high surface concentrations. DRIFTS analysis of CO chemisorption at 2058 cm−1 in the absence of pre-reduction in H2 (Fig. 9b) confirmed the formation of [bipy-RuIIICl3CO] species on Ru PPhenbiby24 (i.e. retention of single site Ru). However, significant reduction of Ru(III) during reaction was seen, with the 16 h used catalyst showing a new binding mode at 2009 cm−1 being attributed to linearly bound CO on Ru(0) nanoparticles. The dispersion of the fresh catalyst after the 150 °C reduction procedure was 10.9 %, dropping to 2.9 % after 2 h of reaction, and only 0.7 % after 16 h reaction. These results confirm that catalyst reduction and sintering during reaction is responsible for the observed deactivation. 3.4 Discussion: Active site and catalyst deactivation Post reaction characterisation shows that in the initial stages of the reaction Ru(0) clusters nucleate from the initial single atom species and sinter over the 16 h reaction. After x4 reactions the Ru(0) particles continue to sinter according to EXAFS but still retain a CN below that of bulk Ru metal. If the active site is assumed to be Ru(0) and given that Ru dispersion was 2.9 % after 2 h (the reaction time used to determine TOF values), the surface normalised TOF for Ru PPhenbiby would be an exceptionally high 33450 h−1. In this case the initial [bipy-RuIIICl4] was simply a precursor to highly active but unstable Ru(0) clusters that then themselves agglomerate. Residual activity would then be attributed to the larger Ru(0) nanoparticles. Given the relatively similar TON values for reused catalysts with different Ru particle sizes (CN from EXAFS of 3(1) for 1x used and 5(2) for 4x used respectively) suggest that the reaction is relatively insensitive to the nanopartile size. This could however be an artifact of the simultaneous water inhibition in the reaction and/or the broadening particle size distribution with reaction time masking clear correlations with particle size. In such a scenario no significant weight should be given to the TOF based on Ru dispersion as the latter is likely to change dramatically over 2 h. Alternatively, it could be speculated that the initial [bipy-RuIIICl4] single site is a highly active but unstable species. Residual activity, seen on the recycling of the catalyst with fresh ethanol, could then be attributed to the small number of single atom species remaining, as observed in the used catalysts by STEM. However, given that the TOF normalised by accessible Ru showed that Ru(0) within the conventionally prepared Ru/C catalyst is active, a scenario in which only single atom [bipy-RuIIICl4] centres are active is improbable. To understand the role of freshly reduced Ru(0) a Ru PPhenbiby was tested after reduction and gave 10.7 % conversion and a TON of 1728 Ru−1 after 16 h. This activity sits between the 3565 and 1000 Ru−1 seen for the unreduced catalyst and reused catalyst respectively. The result verifies that reduced Ru(0) is active although catalyst performance is significantly lower than when starting from initial [bipy-RuIIICl4] single site These findings support the hypothesis that Ru(0) particles produced in-situ on Ru PPhenbipy at the start of the reaction are active. While the absolute value of the Ru surface normalised TOF for Ru PPhenbipy must be treated with great caution, due to the highly dynamic nature of Ru within the reaction and potential for Ru complexes to also be active, it was clear that the intrinsic activity is greater than of the reference Ru/C and homogeneous catalysts under the reaction conditions employed. This could be due the role of the support matrix in either stabilising highly active Ru clusters and/or its hydrophobic promoting reactivity. The influence of water on inhibiting reactivity is clear. High concentrations of water immediately suppress catalytic activity, which can be partially recovered on its removal. Notably the developed Ru PPhenbipy provides an effective combined mitigation strategy of a hydrophobic support, which slows water inhibition, alongside the use of a molecular sieve to remove water and enable high batch conversion of ethanol into n-butanol. The ability to spatially separate an active Ru centre from the molecular sieve prevented deactivation of the Ru site as observed when using a homogeneous catalyst. 4 Conclusion A [bipy-RuCl4] catalyst, with the chelating bipy ligand incorporated into a polyphenylene polymer support (Ru PPhenbipy), has been found to be highly active for the Guerbet ethanol coupling reaction to form n-butanol. Under mild liquid-phase batch reaction conditions of 150 °C, the [bipy-RuIIICl4] catalyst gave initial TOFs of 970 h−1 greater than an established homogeneous Ru catalyst with a TOF of 255 Ru−1 and a reference Ru/C heterogeneous catalyst. As with all tested catalysts, deactivation was observed with Ru PPhenbipy during the batch reaction, due to the formation of water from the aldol condensation reaction step and restructuring of the Ru active site. Deactivation was however less significant for Ru PPhenbipy with a TON of 3565 Ru−1 vs 1073 Ru−1 seen with the homogeneous catalyst. Evidence for water inhibition was proven, with the hydrophobic nature of Ru PPhenbipy reducing sensitivity to water but not completely negating it. Catalytic performance could be partially recovered with conversions of ca 6 %, by removing water from the system by recharging with fresh ethanol. The inclusion of molecular sieve 3 Å into the reaction significantly reduced the impact of water on catalytic performance giving an ethanol conversion of 40.7 % and a TON of 5007 Ru−1. Interestingly, the addition of molecular sieve 3 Å to the homogeneous Ru catalyst at comparable concentrations limited conversion, due to interactions between the catalyst and molecular sieve framework, indicating that this strategy could only be employed with the heterogeneous catalyst under the reaction conditions used. Analysis by Ru K-edge EXAFS and STEM show that the discrete single atom [bipy-RuCl4] structure of the fresh catalyst mostly transforms into Ru(0) clusters after an initial 2 h reaction time. Commensurate with this was the complete loss of Ru-Cl binding as observed from XPS and EXAFS. The high initial activity could be attributed to the single site [bipy-RuCl4] species or more likely highly unstable Ru(0) clusters formed from the initial structural transformation of these sites. Under the reaction conditions employed Ru PPhenbipy was found catalyse the Guerbet reaction more effectively than both established homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Bioethanol upgrading to n-butanol is catalysed by homogeneous catalysts under mild solventless liquid phase conditions, at which heterogeneous catalysts have poor performance. Here a heterogeneous catalyst, initially comprised of a Ru(bipy) complex incorporated into a polyphenylene support, gave a catalytic performance (TON of 3565 Ru−1 and 82 % n-butanol selectivity) that exceeded contemporary homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Catalyst deactivation by water byproduct inhibition was improved by removal of water, via recharging the reactor with fresh ethanol, or by the co-addition of molecular sieve. The Ru polyphenylene catalyst showed greater stability in the presence of molecular sieve compared to the homogeneous catalyst, enabling high butanol yields. Characterisation showed a structural transformation of the single atom Ru(bipy) into 2.6 nm Ru(0) nanoparticles after 16 h reaction. While the Ru(0) had moderate recyclability (TON of 1000 Ru−1) the initial highly active species seen in the fresh catalyst are not stable.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced stability and activity in the upgrading ethanol to n-butanol using a ruthenium polyphenylene catalyst
